P.title: Will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2040, a peer-reviewed scientific study or a credible report from a major technology firm confirms that a human-like artificial intelligence has been created, meeting the following criteria:

- Cognitive Equivalence: The AI demonstrates cognitive abilities at least equal to an average human adult in standardized intelligence tests, including but not limited to IQ tests, memory tests, and problem-solving tasks.

- Emotional and Social Intelligence: The AI exhibits emotional responses and social behaviors that are indistinguishable from those of humans, as assessed by qualified psychologists.

- Continuous Learning: The AI shows the ability to learn new tasks and adapt to new environments at a rate comparable to a human learner.

- Autonomy: The AI operates independently without human intervention for extended periods, making decisions and performing tasks in a manner similar to a human being.

- Ethical and Moral Reasoning: The AI applies ethical and moral reasoning in its decision-making process, as evaluated by an ethics committee.

In the event that multiple AIs meet these criteria, the resolution will be based on the first confirmed instance. If no such AI is developed by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Fallback Scenario: If there is controversy or ambiguity regarding the assessment of the AI's capabilities, a panel of experts from recognized institutions in the field of artificial intelligence will be convened to make a final determination.

Q_given_P.title: Given that human-machine intelligence parity is achieved before 2040, will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as N/A if human-machine intelligence parity is not achieved before 2040. If human-machine intelligence parity is achieved before 2040, this question will resolve as Yes if the European Union officially reports achieving all of the following targets by December 31, 2030, as confirmed by the European Environment Agency (EEA) or another authoritative body designated for this purpose:

- A 40% cut in greenhouse gas emissions (from 1990 levels)
- At least 32% share for renewable energy
- At least 32.5% improvement in energy efficiency

In the event that the European Union redefines its targets under the Paris Climate Treaty before the resolution date, the revised targets will be used to determine the outcome of this question. 

If the European Union dissolves or any member state exits the Union before the resolution date, the question will resolve as No, unless the exiting member state(s) individually meet the targets and their data is included in the overall EU report. 

Should the EEA or the designated authoritative body fail to provide a conclusive report by the resolution date, the question will resolve using the most recent official data available prior to January 1, 2031.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040 AND will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:

1. A peer-reviewed scientific study or a credible report from a major technology firm confirms that a human-like artificial intelligence has been created before January 1, 2040, meeting the following criteria:
   - Cognitive Equivalence: The AI demonstrates cognitive abilities at least equal to an average human adult in standardized intelligence tests, including but not limited to IQ tests, memory tests, and problem-solving tasks.
   - Emotional and Social Intelligence: The AI exhibits emotional responses and social behaviors that are indistinguishable from those of humans, as assessed by qualified psychologists.
   - Continuous Learning: The AI shows the ability to learn new tasks and adapt to new environments at a rate comparable to a human learner.
   - Autonomy: The AI operates independently without human intervention for extended periods, making decisions and performing tasks in a manner similar to a human being.
   - Ethical and Moral Reasoning: The AI applies ethical and moral reasoning in its decision-making process, as evaluated by an ethics committee.

2. The European Union officially reports achieving all of the following targets by December 31, 2030, as confirmed by the European Environment Agency (EEA) or another authoritative body designated for this purpose:
   - A 40% cut in greenhouse gas emissions (from 1990 levels)
   - At least 32% share for renewable energy
   - At least 32.5% improvement in energy efficiency

Fallback Scenarios:
- If there is controversy or ambiguity regarding the assessment of the AI's capabilities, a panel of experts from recognized institutions in the field of artificial intelligence will be convened to make a final determination.
- If the European Union redefines its targets under the Paris Climate Treaty before the resolution date, the revised targets will be used to determine the outcome of this question.
- If the European Union dissolves or any member state exits the Union before the resolution date, the question will resolve as No, unless the exiting member state(s) individually meet the targets and their data is included in the overall EU report.
- Should the EEA or the designated authoritative body fail to provide a conclusive report by the resolution date, the question will resolve using the most recent official data available prior to January 1, 2031.

The question will resolve as NO if either of the conditions is not met.

Q.title: Will the European Union meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty?
Q.body:
The European Union's 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty are defined by the following key objectives: 

- A 40% cut in greenhouse gas emissions (from 1990 levels)
- At least 32% share for renewable energy
- At least 32.5% improvement in energy efficiency

This question will resolve as Yes if the European Union officially reports achieving all of the above targets by December 31, 2030, as confirmed by the European Environment Agency (EEA) or another authoritative body designated for this purpose. 

In the event that the European Union redefines its targets under the Paris Climate Treaty before the resolution date, the revised targets will be used to determine the outcome of this question. 

If the European Union dissolves or any member state exits the Union before the resolution date, the question will resolve as No, unless the exiting member state(s) individually meet the targets and their data is included in the overall EU report. 

Should the EEA or the designated authoritative body fail to provide a conclusive report by the resolution date, the question will resolve using the most recent official data available prior to January 1, 2031.

reasons: The development of human-machine intelligence parity could have significant implications for climate change mitigation efforts, including the European Union's ability to meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty. Advanced AI could potentially accelerate the development of clean technologies, optimize energy systems, and enhance climate modeling and prediction.

The success of the EU in meeting its climate targets could influence the global perception of AI's role in addressing environmental challenges, potentially affecting investment and policy decisions related to AI development.
If AI reaches human-level intelligence and autonomy, it could play a direct role in policy-making and implementation, potentially impacting the EU's environmental strategies and their execution.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential interplay between advanced AI and climate change mitigation efforts, it is reasonable to explore the logical combination of these two forecasting questions. The development of human-machine intelligence parity before 2040 could influence the European Union's ability to meet its 2030 targets under the Paris Climate Treaty, either by accelerating progress or by introducing new variables into the equation.

Q_given_P.title: Given that human-machine intelligence parity is achieved before 2040, will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as N/A if human-machine intelligence parity is not achieved before January 1, 2040. If the condition is met (human-machine intelligence parity achieved before 2040), then this question will resolve as YES if, before January 1, 2050, any of the following conditions are met:

1. An official statement from the United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA) or a similar authoritative international space agency confirms the onset of Kessler syndrome.

2. There is a documented event involving the collision of two or more satellites or significant debris pieces in low Earth orbit (LEO) that results in an exponential increase in debris, as reported by the Space Surveillance Network (SSN) or an equivalent monitoring authority.

3. A peer-reviewed scientific publication presents evidence of a chain reaction of satellite collisions that is consistent with the criteria for Kessler syndrome.

In the absence of direct confirmation, the question may also resolve as YES if there is a consensus among a panel of at least five recognized experts in the field of space debris and orbital mechanics, who agree that Kessler syndrome has occurred based on available data and observations.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be Human-machine intelligence parity before 2040 AND will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:

1. Before January 1, 2040, a peer-reviewed scientific study or a credible report from a major technology firm confirms that a human-like artificial intelligence has been created, meeting the following criteria:

- Cognitive Equivalence: The AI demonstrates cognitive abilities at least equal to an average human adult in standardized intelligence tests, including but not limited to IQ tests, memory tests, and problem-solving tasks.

- Emotional and Social Intelligence: The AI exhibits emotional responses and social behaviors that are indistinguishable from those of humans, as assessed by qualified psychologists.

- Continuous Learning: The AI shows the ability to learn new tasks and adapt to new environments at a rate comparable to a human learner.

- Autonomy: The AI operates independently without human intervention for extended periods, making decisions and performing tasks in a manner similar to a human being.

- Ethical and Moral Reasoning: The AI applies ethical and moral reasoning in its decision-making process, as evaluated by an ethics committee.

In the event that multiple AIs meet these criteria, the resolution will be based on the first confirmed instance. If no such AI is developed by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Fallback Scenario: If there is controversy or ambiguity regarding the assessment of the AI's capabilities, a panel of experts from recognized institutions in the field of artificial intelligence will be convened to make a final determination.

AND

2. Before January 1, 2050, any of the following conditions are met for Kessler syndrome:

- An official statement from the United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA) or a similar authoritative international space agency confirms the onset of Kessler syndrome.

- There is a documented event involving the collision of two or more satellites or significant debris pieces in LEO that results in an exponential increase in debris, as reported by the Space Surveillance Network (SSN) or an equivalent monitoring authority.

- A peer-reviewed scientific publication presents evidence of a chain reaction of satellite collisions that is consistent with the criteria for Kessler syndrome.

In the absence of direct confirmation, the question may also resolve as Yes if there is a consensus among a panel of at least five recognized experts in the field of space debris and orbital mechanics, who agree that Kessler syndrome has occurred based on available data and observations.

Resolves NO otherwise.

Q.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
Q.body:
Kessler syndrome is defined as a scenario in which the density of objects in low Earth orbit (LEO) is high enough that collisions between objects could cause a cascade of collisions, significantly increasing the amount of space debris and hindering future space activities. This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2050, any of the following conditions are met: 

1. An official statement from the United Nations Office for Outer Space Affairs (UNOOSA) or a similar authoritative international space agency confirms the onset of Kessler syndrome.

2. There is a documented event involving the collision of two or more satellites or significant debris pieces in LEO that results in an exponential increase in debris, as reported by the Space Surveillance Network (SSN) or an equivalent monitoring authority.

3. A peer-reviewed scientific publication presents evidence of a chain reaction of satellite collisions that is consistent with the criteria for Kessler syndrome.

In the absence of direct confirmation, the question may also resolve as Yes if there is a consensus among a panel of at least five recognized experts in the field of space debris and orbital mechanics, who agree that Kessler syndrome has occurred based on available data and observations.

reasons: The development of human-machine intelligence parity could lead to advancements in space technology and debris management, potentially reducing the risk of Kessler syndrome.
If Kessler syndrome occurs, it could hinder the development or deployment of AI technologies in space, affecting the timeline for achieving human-machine intelligence parity.
Both events relate to the future of technology and humanity's ability to manage and mitigate risks associated with advanced technologies.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two questions could provide insights into the interplay between advancements in AI and space technology, as well as the potential risks and challenges that could arise from these developments.

P.title: Will a sample of negative energy be produced by 2100?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if a sample of negative energy is produced and confirmed by at least one of the following before January 1, 2100:

- Peer-reviewed publication in a reputable scientific journal that is indexed by major scientific databases such as Web of Science or Scopus.

- Official announcement by a recognized scientific organization or research institution, such as CERN, NASA, or a national laboratory.

- Independent verification by a panel of experts in the field of quantum physics or related disciplines, where the panel is formed by a recognized scientific body or institution.

The sample must be demonstrated to exhibit properties consistent with the current theoretical understanding of negative energy, such as the ability to generate a repulsive gravitational effect. The production process must be replicable, and the results must be reproducible by independent researchers.

In the event that the concept of negative energy is redefined due to advancements in scientific understanding, the resolution criteria will be updated to reflect the new definition, provided that the change occurs before December 31, 2090. If no consensus on the definition is reached by that date, the question will resolve as No.

Q_given_P.title: Given that a sample of negative energy is produced by 2100, will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as N/A if a sample of negative energy is not produced and confirmed by at least one of the following before January 1, 2100:

- Peer-reviewed publication in a reputable scientific journal that is indexed by major scientific databases such as Web of Science or Scopus.

- Official announcement by a recognized scientific organization or research institution, such as CERN, NASA, or a national laboratory.

- Independent verification by a panel of experts in the field of quantum physics or related disciplines, where the panel is formed by a recognized scientific body or institution.

The sample must be demonstrated to exhibit properties consistent with the current theoretical understanding of negative energy, such as the ability to generate a repulsive gravitational effect. The production process must be replicable, and the results must be reproducible by independent researchers.

In the event that the concept of negative energy is redefined due to advancements in scientific understanding, the resolution criteria will be updated to reflect the new definition, provided that the change occurs before December 31, 2090. If no consensus on the definition is reached by that date, the question will resolve as No.

If the condition is met (negative energy is produced by 2100), then this question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, an operational nuclear fusion reactor is developed in China that meets the following criteria:

- Net Positive Energy: The reactor must demonstrate sustained net positive energy output, meaning it produces more energy than it consumes, over a continuous operational period of at least 24 hours.

- Independent Verification: The reactor's performance must be independently verified by an international committee of nuclear scientists recognized by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).

- Public Disclosure: Details of the reactor's design, operation, and performance metrics must be publicly disclosed in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or at an official press conference by the developing organization.

- Commercial Viability: The reactor must be deemed commercially viable, with a clear plan for scaling up to industrial production and a projected timeline.

In the event that multiple countries develop operational nuclear fusion reactors within the same calendar year, this question will resolve as Yes only if China's reactor is the first to be publicly disclosed and verified according to the above criteria.

If no such reactor is developed by the resolution date, or if a reactor is developed but does not meet all of the specified criteria, the question will resolve as No.

P_and_Q.title: Will a sample of negative energy be produced by 2100 AND will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China by 2035?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:

1. A sample of negative energy is produced and confirmed by at least one of the following before January 1, 2100:
   - Peer-reviewed publication in a reputable scientific journal that is indexed by major scientific databases such as Web of Science or Scopus.
   - Official announcement by a recognized scientific organization or research institution, such as CERN, NASA, or a national laboratory.
   - Independent verification by a panel of experts in the field of quantum physics or related disciplines, where the panel is formed by a recognized scientific body or institution.
   The sample must be demonstrated to exhibit properties consistent with the current theoretical understanding of negative energy, such as the ability to generate a repulsive gravitational effect. The production process must be replicable, and the results must be reproducible by independent researchers.
   In the event that the concept of negative energy is redefined due to advancements in scientific understanding, the resolution criteria will be updated to reflect the new definition, provided that the change occurs before December 31, 2090. If no consensus on the definition is reached by that date, the question will resolve as No.

2. An operational nuclear fusion reactor is developed in China that meets the following criteria by December 31, 2035:
   - Net Positive Energy: The reactor must demonstrate sustained net positive energy output, meaning it produces more energy than it consumes, over a continuous operational period of at least 24 hours.
   - Independent Verification: The reactor's performance must be independently verified by an international committee of nuclear scientists recognized by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).
   - Public Disclosure: Details of the reactor's design, operation, and performance metrics must be publicly disclosed in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or at an official press conference by the developing organization.
   - Commercial Viability: The reactor must be deemed commercially viable, with a clear plan for scaling up to industrial production and a projected timeline.
   In the event that multiple countries develop operational nuclear fusion reactors within the same calendar year, this question will resolve as Yes only if China's reactor is the first to be publicly disclosed and verified according to the above criteria.

If no such reactor is developed by the resolution date, or if a reactor is developed but does not meet all of the specified criteria, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, an operational nuclear fusion reactor is developed in China that meets the following criteria:

- Net Positive Energy: The reactor must demonstrate sustained net positive energy output, meaning it produces more energy than it consumes, over a continuous operational period of at least 24 hours.

- Independent Verification: The reactor's performance must be independently verified by an international committee of nuclear scientists recognized by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA).

- Public Disclosure: Details of the reactor's design, operation, and performance metrics must be publicly disclosed in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or at an official press conference by the developing organization.

- Commercial Viability: The reactor must be deemed commercially viable, with a clear plan for scaling up to industrial production and a projected timeline.

In the event that multiple countries develop operational nuclear fusion reactors within the same calendar year, this question will resolve as Yes only if China's reactor is the first to be publicly disclosed and verified according to the above criteria.

If no such reactor is developed by the resolution date, or if a reactor is developed but does not meet all of the specified criteria, the question will resolve as No.

reasons: The development of a practical nuclear fusion reactor could significantly impact global energy production and consumption, potentially leading to advancements in various scientific fields, including those related to negative energy research.

The technological and scientific advancements required for producing a sample of negative energy might be influenced by the broader scientific environment, which could be shaped by major breakthroughs like the development of a nuclear fusion reactor.

China's success in developing a nuclear fusion reactor could indicate a high level of scientific progress and investment in cutting-edge research, which might also contribute to breakthroughs in other areas of physics, such as negative energy.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two questions could be of interest to those studying the interplay between major scientific breakthroughs and their broader impact on the field of physics. It is plausible that success in one area could signal or contribute to advancements in another.

P.title: Will it be legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if at any point before January 1, 2030, the United States Internal Revenue Service officially accepts payments in Bitcoin.
Some crypto payment services work by exchanging the crypto for fiat at the point of transaction, and then sends fiat. That doesn't count -- what the IRS must receive and accept is the Bitcoin.
Show More

Q_given_P.title: Given that it becomes legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030, will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if it does not become legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030. If the condition is met (if it becomes legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030), then this question will resolve as YES if by November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the results of the detection of gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes with statistical significance at the 4-sigma or equivalent level, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will it be legal to pay taxes in the US using bitcoin before 2030 AND will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: a.) At any point before January 1, 2030, the United States Internal Revenue Service officially accepts payments in Bitcoin. The IRS must receive and accept the Bitcoin, not through a service that exchanges crypto for fiat at the point of transaction. b.) By November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the detection of gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes with statistical significance at the 4-sigma or equivalent level. The question will resolve as NO otherwise.

Q.title: Will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as positive if by November 30, 2027, a peer-reviewed publication announces the results of such an event. Statistical significance should be at the 4-sigma or equivalent level.
*(edit 1/1017) November 30 is now a publication date rather than data cutoff date.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
The Nobel Prize-winning detection of gravitational waves added a new observational tool for astronomers to use in studying celestial events. But an as-yet-unobserved phenomenon would make all the gravitational wave detections so far seem like small potatoes.
When two galaxies merge, the supermassive black holes at their centers would merge as well, and the process would emit gravitational waves. But the wavelength of those waves would be undetectable by the LIGO observatory. They're best detected by pulsar.
Pulsars emit electromagnetic radiation at regular intervals. A gravitational wave would slightly change the distance from the Earth to a pulsar, and thus slightly change the pulsar's timing as well.
In a paper in Nature Astronomy, astronomers use observation data and models of supermassive black hole merger events to conclude that we should be able to detect such an event within the next 10 years. If we don't, it could indicate that our .
Show More

P.title: By the year 2100, will any jurisdiction enforce requirements for all births to be genetically engineered?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2100, any jurisdiction passes any law(s) requiring all births to eliminate or promote certain gene(s) through gene editing techniques. "Gene editing techniques" means here CRISPR/Cas9, or any techniques which directly and selectively modify targeted genes. The genetic engineering techniques may occur at any time in the individual's lifespan, including before birth, after birth, or before conception. This question will only include jurisdictions which govern a population of at least 1 million people at the time the law is in effect.
Show More

Q_given_P.title: Given that by the year 2100, any jurisdiction enforces requirements for all births to be genetically engineered, will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as N/A if no jurisdiction passes any law(s) requiring all births to eliminate or promote certain gene(s) through gene editing techniques by January 1, 2100. If such a law is passed in a jurisdiction governing a population of at least 1 million people, then this question will resolve as Yes if the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party, and No otherwise. Gene editing techniques include CRISPR/Cas9 or any techniques which directly and selectively modify targeted genes, and the genetic engineering may occur at any stage in the individual's lifespan.

P_and_Q.title: By the year 2100, will any jurisdiction enforce requirements for all births to be genetically engineered AND will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: a.) Between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2100, any jurisdiction passes any law(s) requiring all births to eliminate or promote certain gene(s) through gene editing techniques, governing a population of at least 1 million people at the time the law is in effect, AND b.) the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Gene editing techniques include CRISPR/Cas9, or any techniques which directly and selectively modify targeted genes. The genetic engineering techniques may occur at any time in the individual's lifespan, including before birth, after birth, or before conception.

P.title: By the year 2100, will any jurisdiction enforce requirements for all births to be genetically engineered?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2100, any jurisdiction passes any law(s) requiring all births to eliminate or promote certain gene(s) through gene editing techniques. "Gene editing techniques" means here CRISPR/Cas9, or any techniques which directly and selectively modify targeted genes. The genetic engineering techniques may occur at any time in the individual's lifespan, including before birth, after birth, or before conception. This question will only include jurisdictions which govern a population of at least 1 million people at the time the law is in effect.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
Our genes are the biologically encoded information from which we are built. Important traits known to be affected by our genes include aspects of intelligence and mental illness. Many physical traits, such as height, attractiveness, strength, and even longevity likewise strongly depend on the genes we have.
As the human genome and related human biological areas of inquiry became better understood, genetic engineering has become known. In the case of traits affected by simple genetic factors, it has been possible for years to change these genes, and the resulting trait(s) expressed, by means such as CRISPR/Cas9.
The pace of genetic engineering research, as measured by papers published worldwide, shows a clear trend to be growing. There is every reason to believe that as a result of this research trend, genetic engineering technology will tend to become safer, more powerful, and less expensive with time.
Show More

Q.title: Will the UK have a Labour Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the UK Prime Minister on January 1, 2030 is a member of the Labour Party.
Otherwise, the question resolves negatively.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
Related Question on Metaculus:
Will the UK have a Conservative Prime Minister on January 1, 2030?
The Labour Party is a centre-left political party in the United Kingdom that has been described as an alliance of social democrats, democratic socialists and trade unionists. The party's platform emphasises greater state intervention, social justice and strengthening workers' rights. As of 2020, it was last in power from 1997 to 2010.

P.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.
Related questions

Q_given_P.title: Given that the USA tops the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024, will the first commercial hyperloop system be within the US by December 31, 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
This question will resolve as N/A if the United States Olympic Team does not achieve the highest rank at the 2024 Paris Olympics or if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. If the USA does top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024, this question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, there is an operational commercial hyperloop system within the United States that meets the following criteria:

- The system must be open to the public and offer regular services.
- The system must cover a minimum distance of 50 miles between two or more stations.
- The system must be capable of achieving and sustaining speeds of at least 600 miles per hour during regular operation.
- The system must have completed all necessary safety inspections and received all required certifications from relevant U.S. regulatory bodies, such as the Department of Transportation and any state-level agencies involved.

In the event that multiple hyperloop systems become operational within the same time frame, the resolution will be based on the date of the first completed passenger journey.

If no commercial hyperloop system is operational in the U.S. by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Fallback scenario: If a hyperloop system is announced to be operational but is not open to the public by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. If the system opens to the public within 30 days after the resolution date, the resolution may be amended to Yes, provided all other criteria are met.

P_and_Q.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024 AND will the first commercial hyperloop system be within the US?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if both of the following conditions are met: a.) the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics, AND b.) by December 31, 2025, there is an operational commercial hyperloop system within the United States that meets the following criteria:

- The system must be open to the public and offer regular services.
- The system must cover a minimum distance of 50 miles between two or more stations.
- The system must be capable of achieving and sustaining speeds of at least 600 miles per hour during regular operation.
- The system must have completed all necessary safety inspections and received all required certifications from relevant U.S. regulatory bodies, such as the Department of Transportation and any state-level agencies involved.

In the event that multiple hyperloop systems become operational within the same time frame, the resolution will be based on the date of the first completed passenger journey.

The question will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team OR if no commercial hyperloop system is operational in the U.S. by the resolution date.

Fallback scenario: If a hyperloop system is announced to be operational but is not open to the public by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. If the system opens to the public within 30 days after the resolution date, the resolution may be amended to Yes, provided all other criteria are met.

P.title: Will USA top the Olympic Medal Table at Paris 2024?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the United States Olympic Team are the (unique) highest ranked team at the 2024 Paris Olympics. It will resolve ambiguously if the Paris Olympics do not take place before 2027. It will resolve negatively if any team achieves a higher or equal ranking to the US team.
Related questions
Show More

metadata.background_info:
The 2024 Olympic games is a sporting competition which takes place every four years. It involves a range of different events across multiple sports.
At the Olympic Games, Gold, Silver and Bronze medals are awarded to 1st, 2nd and 3rd place in each event. (In some events two Bronze medals are awarded mostly combat sports).
The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:
Number of Gold Medals
(Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
(Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals
The US team is one of the most successful teams in recent Olympics, topping the medal table in 2020, 2016, 2012, 2004, 2000. Will they repeat that in 2024?
Show More

Q.title: Will the first commercial hyperloop system be within the US?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, there is an operational commercial hyperloop system within the United States that meets the following criteria:

- The system must be open to the public and offer regular services.
- The system must cover a minimum distance of 50 miles between two or more stations.
- The system must be capable of achieving and sustaining speeds of at least 600 miles per hour during regular operation.
- The system must have completed all necessary safety inspections and received all required certifications from relevant U.S. regulatory bodies, such as the Department of Transportation and any state-level agencies involved.

In the event that multiple hyperloop systems become operational within the same time frame, the resolution will be based on the date of the first completed passenger journey.

If no commercial hyperloop system is operational in the U.S. by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Fallback scenario: If a hyperloop system is announced to be operational but is not open to the public by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. If the system opens to the public within 30 days after the resolution date, the resolution may be amended to Yes, provided all other criteria are met.

P.title: Ragnark Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question resolves Yes if a catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. It resolves No if this occurs for non-AI reasons, and Annulled if no global catastrophe occurs. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.
Show More

Q_given_P.title: Given that a global catastrophe occurs due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode, will lab-grown complex vital organs have been used successfully in humans before 2025?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question resolves N/A if no global catastrophe occurs or if a global catastrophe occurs for non-AI reasons. If a global catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100, then this question will resolve as Yes if before January 1, 2025, any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney or lung. All transplantations need to be considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation.

P_and_Q.title: Ragnarok Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs due to an AI failure-mode AND lab-grown complex vital organs are used successfully in humans before 2025, will both be true?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question resolves Yes if both of the following conditions are met: a.) A catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100, AND b.) Any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney or lung before January 1, 2025. All transplantations need to be considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation.
It resolves No if either a global catastrophe occurs for non-AI reasons, or if no lab-grown complex vital organs are used successfully in humans before 2025, or if both conditions are not met. It resolves Annulled if no global catastrophe occurs.

P.title: Ragnark Question Series: If a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The question resolves Yes if a catastrophe occurs resulting principally from the deployment of some artificial intelligence system(s) that claims at least 10% of the human population in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. It resolves No if this occurs for non-AI reasons, and Annulled if no global catastrophe occurs. Years are here defined as consecutive calendar years.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
You can now see an excellent visualization of global catastrophic risks estimates produced in the Ragnark series here.
Currently, artificial intelligence can outperform humans in a number of narrow domains, such as playing chess and searching data. As artificial intelligence researchers continue to make progress, though, these domains are highly likely to grow in number and breadth over time. Many experts now believe there is a significant chance that a machine superintelligence  a system that can outperform humans at all relevant intelligence tasks  will be developed within the next century, and possibly much sooner.
In a 2017 survey of artificial intelligence experts, the median expert estimated that there is a 50% chance of human-level artificial intelligence by 2062, and after this milestone were reached, respondents reported a 10% chance that superintelligence would be achieved within two years. Our very own question on the prospect of human-machine intelligence parity by 2040 currently has a median prediction of 60%. In another question on the possibility of progress toward human-machine intelligence parity surprising us, a similar median estimate is given.
Show More

Q.title: Will lab-grown complex vital organs be used successfully in humans before 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if before Janury 1 2025, any human lives without the assistance of medical life support for at least 100 days after the implantation of a lab-grown heart, liver (or a substantial part of the liver), kidney or lung.
All transplantations need to be considered by medical professionals to have a substantial positive effect on the patient's health, relative to the counterfactual case in which the patient did not receive the transplantation.
Show More

metadata.background_info:
More than 30,000 organ transplants are performed each year in the United States alone, according to 2015 data from the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network. Around the world, the total was estimated to be 135,860 in 2016 according to the Global Observatory on Donation and Transplantation.
However, the demand for donor organs often significantly exceeds the supply, meaning that many patients have to wait for a significant period of time before receiving an acceptable donor organ. Many, tragically, die waiting.
In response to this problem, multiple efforts are underway around the world to create acceptable donor organs in laboratories. There have been reported successes for simpler tissue structures including vaginas, urethras, and bladders, but so far there have been no attempts in humans for hearts, livers, kidneys or lungs - though lab-grown lungs have been implanted into pigs and functional human mini-kidneys capable of filtering blood to produce urine have been grown in mice.
Show More

reasons: Both questions involve significant advancements in technology and their impacts on humanity.
A global catastrophe due to AI failure-mode could potentially accelerate or decelerate advancements in medical technology, including lab-grown organs.
The successful use of lab-grown organs could be seen as a marker of technological progress, which might correlate with the development and deployment of advanced AI systems.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, as they both pertain to the broader theme of technological impact on humanity.

P.title: Will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if SpaceX successfully lands at least one human on the surface of Mars before December 31, 2030. The landing must be confirmed by at least one of the following authoritative sources: SpaceX official communication, NASA, or the European Space Agency (ESA). The individual(s) must be alive upon landing and must perform at least one extravehicular activity (EVA) on the Martian surface to be considered a successful manned landing. In the event of a dispute regarding the landing, video evidence must be provided showing the individual(s) on the surface of Mars. If SpaceX ceases operations or is acquired by another entity, the resolution will be based on the actions of the successor entity. If no landing has occurred by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Q_given_P.title: Given that SpaceX lands people on Mars before 2030, when the first company reaches a $10 trillion market cap, will it be worth at least double what it was the year before?
Q_given_P.body: This question will resolve as N/A if SpaceX does not successfully land at least one human on the surface of Mars before December 31, 2030. If SpaceX achieves this milestone, the question will then resolve based on the market cap of the first company to reach a $10 trillion valuation. The resolution will be YES if the company's market cap is at least double what it was the year before it reached $10 trillion, and NO otherwise. The landing must be confirmed by at least one of the following authoritative sources: SpaceX official communication, NASA, or the European Space Agency (ESA). The individual(s) must be alive upon landing and must perform at least one extravehicular activity (EVA) on the Martian surface to be considered a successful manned landing. In the event of a dispute regarding the landing, video evidence must be provided showing the individual(s) on the surface of Mars. If SpaceX ceases operations or is acquired by another entity, the resolution will be based on the actions of the successor entity.

P_and_Q.title: Will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030 AND when the first company reaches a $10 trillion market cap, will it be worth at least double what it was the year before?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: 

a.) SpaceX successfully lands at least one human on the surface of Mars before December 31, 2030. The landing must be confirmed by at least one of the following authoritative sources: SpaceX official communication, NASA, or the European Space Agency (ESA). The individual(s) must be alive upon landing and must perform at least one extravehicular activity (EVA) on the Martian surface to be considered a successful manned landing. In the event of a dispute regarding the landing, video evidence must be provided showing the individual(s) on the surface of Mars. If SpaceX ceases operations or is acquired by another entity, the resolution will be based on the actions of the successor entity. If no landing has occurred by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

AND

b.) When the first company reaches a $10 trillion market cap, it will be worth at least double what it was the year before. Company valuations can take off very quickly: Apple was valued at around $100 billion in mid 2007, and so it has taken the company roughly 11 years to grow its market capitalisation by a factor of ten. However, one year before it first hit $1 trillion, it was worth ~$0.8 trillion (which would have resolved a similar question negative).

If either of these conditions is not met, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will SpaceX land people on Mars before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if SpaceX successfully lands at least one human on the surface of Mars before December 31, 2030. The landing must be confirmed by at least one of the following authoritative sources: SpaceX official communication, NASA, or the European Space Agency (ESA). The individual(s) must be alive upon landing and must perform at least one extravehicular activity (EVA) on the Martian surface to be considered a successful manned landing. In the event of a dispute regarding the landing, video evidence must be provided showing the individual(s) on the surface of Mars. If SpaceX ceases operations or is acquired by another entity, the resolution will be based on the actions of the successor entity. If no landing has occurred by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: When the first company reaches a $10 trillion market cap, will it be worth at least double what it was the year before?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Company valuations can take off very quickly: Apple was valued at around $100 billion in mid 2007, and so it has taken the company roughly 11 years to grow its market capitalisation by a factor of ten. However, one year before it first hit $1 trillion, it was worth ~$0.8 trillion (which would have resolved a similar question negative).
Show More

reasons: Technological advancements and economic growth are often correlated. A successful manned mission to Mars by SpaceX could signify a period of rapid technological progress, which might also drive significant economic growth and market valuations.
SpaceX's success could boost investor confidence in technology companies, potentially accelerating the growth of market caps, including the first company to reach a $10 trillion market cap.
Elon Musk, the CEO of SpaceX, is also the CEO of Tesla, a company that could be a candidate for reaching a $10 trillion market cap. Success in one venture could positively influence the other.
relevance.conclusion: There are plausible reasons to consider the logical combination of these questions, especially given the potential technological and economic impacts of a successful Mars mission.

P.title: Will Metaculus exist in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A positive resolution does not require the site to still operate at metaculus.com in 2030, but it does require a degree of continuity with the current version of Metaculus so that no more than 1% of all predictions ever made may have been lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions may have been lost.
Due to the nature of this question the best point optimizing prediction would be 99%, no matter of the real probability of Metaculus existing in 2030, as a non-existent Metaculus cannot make you lose points. Still, players are urged to predict in good faith

Q_given_P.title: Given that Metaculus will exist in 2030, will one government govern 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: A positive resolution for the existence of Metaculus in 2030 does not require the site to still operate at metaculus.com, but it does require a degree of continuity with the current version of Metaculus so that no more than 1% of all predictions ever made may have been lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions may have been lost. Players are urged to predict in good faith.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations.

The question resolves N/A if Metaculus does not exist in 2030. If Metaculus does exist in 2030, the question then resolves YES if a single government governs 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will Metaculus exist in 2030 AND will one government govern 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Metaculus:
A positive resolution requires a degree of continuity with the current version of Metaculus so that no more than 1% of all predictions ever made may have been lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions may have been lost.

Resolution Criteria for Earth Government:
This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations.

The question resolves YES if both Metaculus exists in 2030 according to the specified criteria AND a single government governs 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Metaculus exist in 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A positive resolution does not require the site to still operate at metaculus.com in 2030, but it does require a degree of continuity with the current version of Metaculus so that no more than 1% of all predictions ever made may have been lost from players' point calculating process and no more than one percent of once opened questions may have been lost.
Due to the nature of this question the best point optimizing prediction would be 99%, no matter of the real probability of Metaculus existing in 2030, as a non-existent Metaculus cannot make you lose points. Still, players are urged to predict in good faith

metadata.background_info: Due to the fact that some of Metaculus' questions (and some of the most interesting/important ones for that) are extremely long-term, some users have expressed concern that Metaculus will not be around for resolution. While whether Metaculus will be around to resolve very long-term questions may not be of direct interest to predictors, as it does not really make sense to predict with points in mind if those points are decades away anyway, it would still be interesting to get a sense of what the probability is that Metaculus will be around in a couple of decades time.

Q.title: Will one government govern 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if a single government rules over 80% of Earth population and 80% of Earth GDP at any point before January 1st 2100. An organisation would be considered an Earth government if it has supreme military authority in its territory, a unified foreign policy and the power to collect taxes and make laws. This would include the 2021 United States and exclude the 2021 European Union or United Nations
Show More

metadata.background_info: China is currently the most populous county in the world, with 17.9% of the global population. Historically, only various Chinese empires and the Mongol and Roman Empires have exceeded 30% of the global population. This question asks if by 2100, there will be a centralised government ruling over 80% of the world's population, and accounting for over 80% of global GDP.

reasons: Metaculus is a platform for forecasting and predicting future events, and its existence in 2030 could be influenced by significant geopolitical changes, such as the emergence of a single global government.

A single government governing 80% of Earth's population and economy by 2100 would be a monumental shift in global politics and economics, potentially affecting many aspects of society, including platforms like Metaculus.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions is somewhat relevant because significant geopolitical changes could impact the existence of forecasting platforms like Metaculus.
